elements.label: Gildersleeve's Latin Grammar
elements.description: Just what you need to refresh your knowledge of Latin.

elements.label: The Journal of Alessandro LaCroce
elements.description: Prince Alessandro LaCroce spent years in secret study of the tablets taken from the Fucine Marshes in central Italy. His work will allow you to decipher Fucine texts.

elements.label: Kühner and Gerth
elements.description: Kühner and Gerth's 'Ausführliche Grammatik der griechischen Sprache' - a Greek grammar. An essential weapon for a ferocious struggle with a challenging language.

elements.label: The Velshorn Inscriptions
elements.description: An epic and notably erotic poem describing a rash musician's couplings with, and eventual flaying by, the Red Mother - in both Greek and Phrygian. The intrepid Cal Velshorn found these inscriptions on a temple wall in Halicarnassus, but the same inscription has turned up in a surprising number of other places. [If you speak Greek, you can use this to learn Phrygian.]

elements.label: THE MAGUS VON BRANDT'S AUTHENTIC AND UNIQUE ACCOUNT OF THE TRUE TONGUE OF THE TRUE HOLY LAND OF THE HIGHMOST
elements.description: Written excitably and in some haste by a gentleman in the grip of a Transcendentalist enthusiasm, but nevertheless a useful guide to Aramaic.

elements.label: The August Stone
elements.description: A tremendous bowl, big as a gong, carved from black basalt, bearing an incantation against demons in Deep Mandaic. The underside bears the same incantation in Aramaic. [If you speak Aramaic, you can use this to learn Deep Mandaic.]

elements.label: Gartside's Sanskrit Reader
elements.description: A lucid book which outlines a careful path through the thickets of a vast and complex language.

elements.label: The Uyrus
elements.description: An elaborate ivory sculpture of impossible intricacy. Around and across its surfaces, Sanskrit inscriptions spiral against matching lines of Vak. [If you speak Sanskrit, you can use this to learn Vak, the first language of the world.]
